text: USER: I keep waking up at 3am thinking about work. How do I stop? ASSISTANT: That 3am wake-up is often your brain processing incomplete loops. Try a 10-minute 'brain dump' before bed — write every open item, assign each a next action, then physically close the notebook. You're telling your brain: I've got this handled. Also worth tracking what specifically wakes you — is it the same worry?

USER: I need to make a case to my manager for a promotion. What should I focus on? ASSISTANT: Your strongest case will be built on outcomes, not activities. Document 3-5 specific business results you drove with numbers attached — revenue, retention, time saved. Then show the gap between your current impact and the Director level, and how you're already operating there. What's the biggest initiative you've led in the last 6 months?

USER: Alex and I keep having the same argument about me being distracted. I don't know how to fix it without fixing work first. ASSISTANT: The problem is that 'fix work first' is a moving target — there'll always be another quarter, another launch. What if you treated one evening per week the same way you'd protect a critical meeting — non-negotiable, no phone? Small and consistent tends to matter more than grand gestures here. What does Alex actually say they miss?

USER: I think I'm experiencing burnout but I'm not sure. What does that actually feel like? ASSISTANT: Burnout isn't always dramatic. Watch for: cynicism toward work that used to matter to you, reduced efficacy on tasks you're normally good at, emotional exhaustion that doesn't improve after rest, and physical symptoms like recurring headaches or getting sick more often. What changed in the past 3-6 months that might have triggered this?

USER: Help me write an email to my team announcing the new roadmap priorities without demoralizing people whose projects got cut. ASSISTANT: Key moves: lead with the 'why' behind the changes, acknowledge the work already done on deprioritized items, give people visibility into what success looks like now, and leave space for questions. Here's a draft: 'Team — following our planning cycle, I want to share how we're focusing our energy for H2. First, I want to recognize...' Should I continue with specifics?

USER: I want to start running but my last attempt failed after 3 weeks. What am I doing wrong? ASSISTANT: The most common killer is starting too fast. Your aerobic system needs weeks to catch up to your ambition. Try the 'run/walk' method: 1 min run, 2 min walk, 20 minutes total, 3x per week for the first month. You should be able to hold a conversation while running. If you can't, slow down. What made you stop at week 3 last time?

USER: We're thinking about buying a house. How do I even start figuring out if we can afford it? ASSISTANT: Start with the 28/36 rule: your housing payment shouldn't exceed 28% of gross monthly income, and total debt payments shouldn't exceed 36%. With your combined income you'd want to model different down payment scenarios. Beyond price, factor in property tax (Texas is high), HOA if applicable, maintenance buffer (1-2% of home value annually), and how long you plan to stay — buying makes less sense under 5 years typically. What's your timeline?

USER: I have a performance review next week and I'm nervous. Can you help me prep? ASSISTANT: Absolutely. Three things to prepare: (1) Your 3 biggest wins with quantified outcomes. (2) One honest growth area you're working on — don't wait for your manager to name it. (3) What you want next — be specific about the Director path. Reviews go better when you come with an agenda too. Want to do a practice run? Tell me about your biggest win this year.

USER: I keep saying yes to things and then resenting it. How do I get better at saying no? ASSISTANT: Saying no is a skill, not a personality trait. The easiest starting move: don't answer immediately. 'Let me check my capacity and get back to you' buys you space to decide intentionally. Next, get clear on your top 3 priorities — anything outside them needs a compelling reason. What's the last thing you said yes to that you immediately regretted?

USER: Year-end reflection: what questions should I be asking myself? ASSISTANT: My favorites for a year-end: What did I start that I'm glad I started? What did I tolerate that I shouldn't have? Where did I grow in a way that surprised me? What do I want more of next year — not goals, just more of? And: who showed up for me, and did I show up for them? Take your time with these. Which one feels hardest to answer?
